Class java.lang.__DEBUG 

java.lang.Object
   |
   +----java.lang.__DEBUG
public final class __DEBUG
extends Object
The __DEBUG class has several interesting methods which may aid in debugging. Note that these methods arguably break the security of Java, so the __DEBUG class is not typically available except in a development environment.

REF_CSTACK
label for traceAddress references to conservative stack (i.e., maybe a pointer)
REF_FINAL
label for traceAddress references to finalization queue
REF_GLOBAL
label for traceAddress references to global space
REF_HEAP
label for traceAddress references to heap (normal objects)
REF_INTERN
label for traceAddress references to intern tables
REF_OTHER
catch-all label for traceAddress references
REF_STACK
label for traceAddress references to nonconservative stack (i.e., definitely a pointer)
REF_STATIC
label for traceAddress references to static variables

addressOf(Object)
Return the address of the given object as an int.
addressString(int, int)
Get a string for the given address, with the given number of digits or more.
kindString(int)
Turn a refKind as returned by traceAddress into a human-readable string.
memoryDump()
Spit out a gimongo dump of memory to the console.
objectify(int)
Turn an int address into an object.
parseAddress(String)
Turn a string of hex digits into a munged address.
traceAddress(int, int[], int[])
Get a trace of the addresses that refer to the given address.

addressOf 
 public static native int addressOf(Object o)
Return the address of the given object as an int.

Parameters:
o - the object to get the address of
Returns:
the address of the object as an int
objectify 
 public static native Object objectify(int addr)
Turn an int address into an object. Note that this is a highly dangerous operation, since it implicitly ignores all of Java's normal type safety.

Parameters:
addr - the address of the object
Returns:
the object at the given address
traceAddress 
 public static native int traceAddress(int addr,
                                       int refs[],
                                       int refKinds[])
Get a trace of the addresses that refer to the given address. This can be used to figure out why a given object isn't getting garbage collected when you think it should be. The results are "returned" as the elements of the two arrays of int passed in as arguments. The first array contains the addresses of the references, and the second contains the "kind" of each reference (stack, heap, etc.).

Parameters:
addr - the address of the object to back-trace @param refs the returned array of references @param refKinds the returned array of reference kinds @return the number of references found. If this number is larger than the actual size of the arrays passed in, then it is an indication that there were more references than could be held by the arrays.
memoryDump 
 public static native void memoryDump()
Spit out a gimongo dump of memory to the console. Not recommended for the faint of heart.

kindString 
 public static String kindString(int kind)
Turn a refKind as returned by traceAddress into a human-readable string.

Parameters:
kind - the refKind
Returns:
the kind as a string
addressString 
 public static String addressString(int address,
                                    int minLen)
Get a string for the given address, with the given number of digits or more. The result will always have at least one digit. Note that while the address as an int is munged, the string is not. However, the code that does this at no time holds onto any of the actual (unmunged) address bits.

Parameters:
address - the address to stringify
minLen - the minimum length of the string (if it would be shorter, it pads the left with zeroes)
Returns:
the address as a string
parseAddress 
 public static int parseAddress(String address)
Turn a string of hex digits into a munged address. Note that while the string is an unmunged address, at no time does the code hold onto the unmunged address as an unmunged int.

Parameters:
address - the string of the address
Returns:
the munged address as an int
